title: Credit card detail theft (fake 'confirm address' / payment pages)
summary: Scammers try to steal your card details by sending you to a fake payment page (often pretending to be a delivery service).
how_it_works: You get a text/email claiming there’s a delivery problem and you must 'confirm address' or pay a small fee.
The link opens a website that looks real and asks for card number, expiry, and CVV.
Once entered, scammers use the card details or sell them.
warning_signs: Message says you must pay a small 'redelivery' or 'processing' fee.
Link goes to a weird domain (not the official delivery company).
The form asks for full card details for something that should be free or handled in-app.
example_hooks: “Unpaid fee — your parcel will be returned today.”
what_to_do: Don’t enter card details from a link in a message.
Track parcels only via the official delivery app/site you open yourself.
If you entered details, contact your bank/card provider immediately to stop transactions.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
